CHAIRMAN  RAMRAS  announced  that  the  next  order  of  business                                                                    
would  be  CS  FOR  HOUSE  BILL  NO.  301(FIN),  "An  Act  making                                                                    
conforming  amendments  to  the  Alaska  Liquor  Control  Law;                                                                    
relating to the issuance of liquor licenses; and providing for                                                                    
an effective date."                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                
Number 0280                                                                                                                     
                                                                                                                                
REPRESENTATIVE  JOHN  HARRIS,  Alaska  State  Legislature,  Juneau,                                                                    
Alaska,  sponsor  of  HB  301(FIN),  advised  that  the  bill                                                                    
contains  a  number  of  technical  amendments  to  the  Alaska                                                                    
Liquor  Control  Law  that  were  identified  by  the  Department                                                                    
of  Revenue  and  the  Alcoholic  Beverage  Control  Board  (ABC                                                                    
Board)  during  the  2001  legislative  session  and  the  2002                                                                    
interim.  He  noted  that  the  bill  also  contains  a  number                                                                    
amendments  that  were  identified  by  the  ABC  Board  during                                                                    
the 2003 legislative session.  Representative Harris explained:

Question 1: Which of the following statements is true? a) The number 1 is a prime number. b) The number 0 is a prime number. c) The number 2 is the smallest prime number. d) The number 1 is not a prime number. Answer: d) The number 1 is not a prime number. Explanation: A prime number is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself. The number 1 only has one positive divisor, which is 1, so it does not meet the criteria to be a prime number.

Question 2: Which of the following numbers is a prime number? a) 11 b) 15 c) 19 d) 21 Answer: a) 11 and c) 19. Explanation: A prime number is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself. The number 11 has only two positive divisors, which are 1 and 11, so it is a prime number. The number 19 also has only two positive divisors, which are 1 and 19, so it is also a prime number. The number 15 has three positive divisors, which are 1, 3, and 5, so it is not a prime number. The number 21 has four positive divisors, which are 1, 3, 7, and 21, so it is also not a prime number.

Question 3: Which of the following statements is true? a) Every even number is a prime number. b) Every odd number is a prime number. c) There are infinitely many prime numbers. d) There are only a finite number of prime numbers. Answer: c) There are infinitely many prime numbers. Explanation: A prime number is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself. The ancient Greek mathematician Euclid proved that there are infinitely many prime numbers by using a proof by contradiction. The proof is as follows: Assume that there are only a finite number of prime numbers, say p1, p2, ..., pn. Consider the number P = (p1 \* p2 \* ... \* pn) + 1. This number is greater than all of the prime numbers, so it cannot be any of them. However, P is either prime or composite. If P is prime, then we have found a new prime number that is not in our list, which is a contradiction. If P is composite, then it must have a prime factor, say q. Since q is a prime factor of P, it must divide P. However, q also divides (p1 \* p2 \* ... \* pn), so it must divide the difference P - (p1 \* p2 \* ... \* pn) = 1, which is impossible. Therefore, our assumption that there are only a finite number of prime numbers is false, and there must be infinitely many prime numbers.

    follow = User.all.order("RANDOM()").first
    if user != follow
      follow.follow(user)
    end
  end

  # Relationships with no follower
  10.times do
    user  = User.all.order("RANDOM()").first
    user.follow(nil)
  end

  # Relationships with no following
  10.times do
    user  = User.all.order("RANDOM()").first
    user.followed_by(nil)
  end

end

'. User-generated content (UGC), such as reviews and testimonials, can be a powerful tool in building trust and credibility with potential customers.

### 5. Optimize for Mobile

More and more people are using their mobile devices to search for local businesses. Make sure your website is optimized for mobile devices, with a responsive design that adjusts to different screen sizes. This will not only improve the user experience for mobile visitors, but it can also help to improve your search engine rankings.

### 6. Use Local SEO Techniques

Local SEO is a set of techniques that can help your business to rank higher in local search results. This includes optimizing your website for local keywords, creating a Google My Business listing, and building local citations on other websites.

### 7. Engage with Your Community

Building relationships with other local businesses and organizations can help to increase your visibility in the community. This can include sponsoring local events, participating in community groups, and collaborating with other businesses on joint promotions.

### 8. Monitor Your Online Reputation

Keep an eye on what people are saying about your business online, and respond promptly to any negative reviews or feedback. This can help to mitigate the damage and show that you take customer feedback seriously.

### 9. Use Social Media

Social media can be a powerful tool for local businesses, allowing you to connect with potential customers and build a community around your brand. Make sure you have a strong presence on the social media platforms that are most relevant to your business, and post regular updates to keep your followers engaged.

### 10. Measure Your Results

Finally, it's important to track your progress and measure the results of your marketing efforts. This can help you to identify what's working and what's not, and make adjustments to your strategy as needed. Use tools like Google Analytics to track website traffic and conversions, and social media analytics to measure engagement and reach.

By following these tips, you can create a strong local marketing strategy that will help you to attract new customers and grow your business. Remember to stay focused on your target audience, build relationships with other local businesses, and measure your results to ensure that you're making progress toward your goals. With the right approach, you can build a successful local business that stands out from the competition.

 #include <iostream>
 #include <string>
 #include <vector>

 int main()
 {
     std::string s;
     std::cin >> s;
     std::vector<int> v;
     for (int i = 0; i < s.size(); ++i) {
         if (s[i] == '1') {
             v.push_back(i);
         }
     }

     if (v.size() == 0) {
         std::cout << 0 << std::endl;
         return 0;
     }

     int ans = 0;
     for (int i = 0; i < v.size() - 1; ++i) {
         ans += v[i + 1] - v[i] - 1;
     }
     std::cout << ans << std::endl;
     return 0;
 }

  (defun my-org-export-to-pdf (arg &optional async subtreep visible-only body-only ext-plist)
    "Export current buffer to LaTeX then process to PDF.

  If narrowing is active in the current buffer, only export its
  narrowed part.

  If a region is active, export that region.

  A non-nil optional argument ASYNC means the process should happen
  asynchronously.  The resulting file should be accessible through
  the `org-export-stack' interface.

  When optional argument SUBTREEP is non-nil, export the sub-tree
  at point, extracting information from the headline properties
  first.

  When optional argument VISIBLE-ONLY is non-nil, don't export
  contents of hidden elements.

  When optional argument BODY-ONLY is non-nil, only produce the
  body of document, not the preamble or postamble.

  EXT-PLIST, when provided, is a property list with external
  parameters overriding Org default settings, but still inferior to
  file-local settings.

  Export is done in a buffer named \"*Org PDF LaTeX Export*\", which
  will be displayed when T is non-nil."
    (interactive "P")
    (if async
        (org-export-async-start
         (lambda (file)
           (if (file-exists-p file)
               (org-open-file (expand-file-name file))
             (message "Failed to create PDF file")))
         (let ((org-export-latex-create-formula-image-program 'mathjax)
               (org-export-latex-pdf-process
                '("latexmk -f -pdf -%latexoption -interaction=nonstopmode -output-directory %o %f")))
           (org-export-to-pdf nil subtreep visible-only body-only ext-plist)))
      (let ((org-export-latex-create-formula-image-program 'mathjax)
            (org-export-latex-pdf-process
             '("latexmk -f -pdf -%latexoption -interaction=nonstopmode -output-directory %o %f")))
        (org-export-to-pdf nil subtreep visible-only body-only ext-plist)))))
  #+END_SRC
```

Comment: I've added the code to the question.

## Answer (0)

I've found a solution.

The problem was that the `org-export-latex-pdf-process` variable was being set in the `my-org-export-to-pdf` function, but the `org-latex-to-pdf-process` variable was being used in the `org-latex-compile` function.

I've changed the `my-org-export-to-pdf` function to set the `org-latex-to-pdf-process` variable instead of the `org-export-latex-pdf-process` variable, and now it works as expected.

Here's the updated code:

```
(defun my-org-export-to-pdf (arg &optional async subtreep visible-only body-only ext-plist)
  "Export current buffer to LaTeX then process to PDF.

  If narrowing is active in the current buffer, only export its
  narrowed part.

  If a region is active, export that region.

  A non-nil optional argument ASYNC means the process should happen
  asynchronously.  The resulting file should be accessible through
  the `org-export-stack' interface.

  When optional argument SUBTREEP is non-nil, export the sub-tree
  at point, extracting information from the headline properties
  first.

  When optional argument VISIBLE-ONLY is non-nil, don't export
  contents of hidden elements.

  When optional argument BODY-ONLY is non-nil, only produce the
  body of document, not the preamble or postamble.

  EXT-PLIST, when provided, is a property list with external
  parameters overriding Org default settings, but still inferior to
  file-local settings.

  Export is done in a buffer named \"*Org PDF LaTeX Export*\", which
  will be displayed when T is non-nil."
  (interactive "P")
  (if async
      (org-export-async-start
       (lambda (file)
         (if (file-exists-p file)
             (org-open-file (expand-file-name file))
           (message "Failed to create PDF file")))
       (let ((org-latex-to-pdf-process
              '("latexmk -f -pdf -%latexoption -interaction=nonstopmode -output-directory %o %f")))
         (org-export-to-pdf nil subtreep visible-only body-only ext-plist)))
    (let ((org-latex-to-pdf-process
           '("latexmk -f -pdf -%latexoption -interaction=nonstopmode -output-directory %o %f")))
      (org-export-to-pdf nil subtreep visible-only body-only ext-plist)))))
```

C

 User.create!(
     name:  "Example User",
     email: "example@railstutorial.org",
     password:              "foobar",
     password_confirmation: "foobar",
     admin: true,
     activated: true,
     activated_at: Time.zone.now
   )
  99.times do |n|
    name  = Faker::Name.name
    email = "example-#{n+1}@railstutorial.org"
    password = "password"
    User.create!(
      name:  name,
      email: email,
      password:              password,
      password_confirmation: password,
      activated: true,
      activated_at: Time.zone.now
    )
  end

  # Following relationships
  users = User.all
  user  = users.first
  following = users[2..50]
  followers = users[3..40]
  following.each { |followed| user.follow(followed) }
  followers.each { |follower| follower.follow(user) }

  # Create topics
  topics = []
  10.times do
    topics << Topic.create!(
      name: Faker::Lorem.word,
      description: Faker::Lorem.sentence,
      user: users.sample
    )
  end

  # Create posts
  posts = []
  10.times do
    posts << Post.create!(
      title: Faker::Lorem.word,
      content: Faker::Lorem.paragraph,
      user: users.sample,
      topic: topics.sample
    )
  end

  # Create comments
  comments = []
  10.times do
    comments << Comment.create!(
      content: Faker::Lorem.paragraph,
      user: users.sample,
      post: posts.sample
    )
  end
end

 package main

 import "fmt"

 func main() {
     fmt.Println("Hello, World!")
 }

```

This is a simple program that prints "Hello, World!" to the console.

To run the program, you can use the `go run` command followed by the name of the file:
```
$ go run hello.go
Hello, World!
```
You can also use the `go build` command to compile the program into an executable file, which you can then run directly:
```
$ go build hello.go
$ ./hello
Hello, World!
```

## Variables

In Go, you can declare variables using the `var` keyword. For example:
```
var x int = 10
var y string = "hello"
```
You can also use shorthand syntax to declare and initialize a variable in a single line:
```
x := 10
y := "hello"
```
You can declare multiple variables in a single line by separating them with commas:
```
x, y := 10, "hello"
```

## Data Types

Go has several built-in data types, including:

* `int`: a signed integer type
* `float64`: a floating-point number type
* `bool`: a boolean type (`true` or `false`)
* `string`: a sequence of characters

You can also define your own data types using the `type` keyword. For example:
```
type MyInt int
```
This creates a new data type called `MyInt` that is equivalent to the built-in `int` type.

## Control Flow

Go has several control flow statements, including `if`, `else`, `for`, and `switch`.

Here is an example of an `if` statement:
```
x := 10
if x > 0 {
    fmt.Println("x is positive")
}
```
You can use an `else` clause to specify an alternative action:
```
x := 10
if x > 0 {
    fmt.Println("x is positive")
} else {
    fmt.Println("x is non-positive")
}
```
You can use a `for` loop to iterate over a sequence of values. For example:
```
for i := 0; i < 10; i++ {
    fmt.Println(i)
}
```
You can use a `switch` statement to choose from a set of possible values. For example:
```
x := 10
switch x {
case 0:
    fmt.Println("x is zero")
case 1:
    fmt.Println("x is one")
default:
    fmt.Println("x is something else")
}
```

## Functions

In Go, you can define functions using the `func` keyword. For example:
```
func add(x int, y int) int {
    return x + y
}
```
This defines a function called `add` that takes two `int` arguments and returns an `int` result.

You can call a function by using its name followed by a list of arguments in parentheses:
```
result := add(1, 2)
```
Functions can also return multiple values. For example:
```
func divide(x int, y int) (int, int) {
    return x / y, x % y
}

quotient, remainder := divide(10, 3)
```

## Structs

In Go, you can define a struct to group together related values. For example:
```
type Point struct {
    x int
    y int
}
```
This defines a struct called `Point` with two fields: `x` and `y`.

You can create an instance of a struct using the `&` operator to create a pointer to the struct:
```
p := &Point{1, 2}
```
You can access the fields of a struct using the dot notation:
```
fmt.Println(p.x) // prints 1
fmt.Println(p.y) // prints 2
```

## Interfaces

In Go, you can define an interface to specify a set of methods that a type must implement. For example:
```
type Shape interface {
    area() float64
}
```
This defines an interface called `Shape` with a single method called `area` that returns a `float64` value.

You can then define a type that implements the `Shape` interface by implementing the `area` method:
```
type Rectangle struct {
    width  float64
    height float64
}

func (r *Rectangle) area() float64 {
    return r.width * r.height
}
```
You can use an interface type as a function argument or return value to specify that a function can accept or return any type that implements the interface. For example:
```
func printArea(s Shape) {
    fmt.Println(s.area())
}

r := &Rectangle{10, 20}
printArea(r) // prints 200
```

## Packages

In Go, you can organize your code into packages to make it easier to reuse and share. A package is a collection of related files that are stored in a single directory.

To create a package, you simply need to create a directory with the desired package name and place your Go source files in it. For example:
```
myproject/
    main.go
    math/
        add.go
        subtract.go
```
In this example, `main.go` is the main program, and `math` is a package that contains two functions: `add` and `subtract`.

To use a package in your code, you need to import it using the `import` keyword. For example:
```
import "myproject/math"

result := math.Add(1, 2)
```

## Concurrency

Go has built-in support for concurrent programming using goroutines and channels.

A goroutine is a lightweight thread of execution that can run concurrently with other goroutines. You can start a goroutine by using the `go` keyword followed by a function call:
```
go func() {
    fmt.Println("Hello from a goroutine!")
}()
```
You can use channels to communicate between goroutines. A channel is a communication mechanism that allows you to send and receive values between goroutines.

Here is an example of using a channel to synchronize two goroutines:
```
c := make(chan int)

go func() {
    c <- 1
}()

go func() {
    <-c
    fmt.Println("Received value from channel!")
}()
```
In this example, the first goroutine sends the value `1` to the channel, and the second goroutine receives the value from the channel. This causes the second goroutine to block until the value is available, allowing the two goroutines to synchronize their execution.

You can use channels to implement a variety of concurrent patterns, such as producer-consumer, fan-out, and fan-in.

## Error Handling

In Go, you can use the `error` type to represent errors that may occur in your code. You can define your own error values using the `errors` package or by using the `errors.New` function.

Here is an example of using an error value to indicate that a function has failed:
```
func divide(x int, y int) (int, error) {
    if y == 0 {
        return 0, errors.New("cannot divide by zero")
    }
    return x / y, nil
}

quotient, err := divide(10, 0)
if err != nil {
    fmt.Println(err)
    return
}
fmt.Println(quotient)
```
In this example, the `divide` function returns an error value if the second argument is zero. The calling code can then check the error value and take appropriate action if an error has occurred.

## Delivery Options

When you can't wait for your order to arrive. Order by 10 a.m., and your order will be delivered to you on the very same day before 7 p.m.

### Next-Day Delivery

## Answer (2)

The answer is yes, but it's a bit more complicated than that.

The reason is that there's no single "right" answer to this question. Instead, the answer depends on the specific context in which the question is being asked.

For example, if the question is being asked in the context of a scientific research study, then the answer will depend on the specific details of the study, such as the research question being addressed, the study design, the sample size, the data collection methods, and the statistical analysis plan.

On the other hand, if the question is being asked in the context of a high school or college class, then the answer will depend on the specific course and the level of the course.

For example, if the question is being asked in the context of an introductory statistics course, then the answer will depend on the specific course and the level of the course. In an introductory course, the answer might be that the sample size is typically small, the data are typically collected through surveys or experiments, and the statistical analysis is typically done using basic statistical methods such as t-tests, chi-square tests, and ANOVA.

However, if the question is being asked in the context of a more advanced statistics course, then the answer might be different. In a more advanced course, the sample size might be larger, the data might be collected through more sophisticated methods, and the statistical analysis might be more complex.

So, in summary, the answer to the question "How do you do a statistical analysis?" depends on the specific context in which the question is being asked. The answer will vary depending on the research question being addressed, the study design, the sample size, the data collection methods, and the statistical analysis plan.

## Answer (1)

The answer is yes.

The reason is that the 1992 version of the C standard (ISO/IEC 9899:1992) explicitly states that the `main` function can be declared with a return type of `int`.

The relevant quote from the standard is:

> **5.1.2.2.1**
>
> The function called `main` shall have a return type of `int`.

The same applies to the C++ standard (ISO/IEC 14882:1998).

The relevant quote from the C++ standard is:

> **3.6.1/1**
>
> The function called `main` shall have a return type of `int`.

 package com.example.demo.controller;

import com.example.demo.model.User;
import com.example.demo.service.UserService;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.*;

import java.util.List;

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {

    @Autowired
    private UserService userService;

    @GetMapping
    public List<User> getAllUsers() {
        return userService.getAllUsers();
    }

    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    public User getUserById(@PathVariable Long id) {
        return userService.getUserById(id);
    }

    @PostMapping
    public User createUser(@RequestBody User user) {
        return userService.createUser(user);
    }

    @PutMapping("/{id}")
    public User updateUser(@PathVariable Long id, @RequestBody User user) {
        return userService.updateUser(id, user);
    }

    @DeleteMapping("/{id}")
    public void deleteUser(@PathVariable Long id) {
        userService.deleteUser(id);
    }
}

## The Four Friends and the Lost Key

Once upon a time, there were four friends named #1, #2, #3, and #4. They were the best of friends and did everything together.

One day, they decided to go on a camping trip in the woods. They packed their bags and set off on the long hike to their campsite.

When they finally arrived, they set up their tents and started a fire. They cooked dinner and sat around the fire, telling stories and laughing.

But as the night wore on, they started to get tired. One by one, they went to their tents and went to sleep.

The next morning, they woke up early and started to pack up their things. But as they were getting ready to leave, they realized that one of them had lost the key to the car.

They searched high and low, but they couldn't find it anywhere. They were starting to get worried. They had to get back home, but they couldn't do it without the key.

Just when they were about to give up, #1 had an idea.

"Hey, remember that old cabin we passed on the way here?" #1 said. "Maybe we can find a spare key there."

The others agreed, and they set off to find the cabin. When they got there, they searched all around, but they couldn't find a spare key.

Just when they were about to give up, #2 had an idea.

"Hey, remember that old tree we passed on the way here?" #2 said. "Maybe we can find a spare key there."

The others agreed, and they set off to find the tree. When they got there, they searched all around, but they couldn't find a spare key.

Just when they were about to give up, #3 had an idea.

"Hey, remember that old well we passed on the way here?" #3 said. "Maybe we can find a spare key there."

The others agreed, and they set off to find the well. When they got there, they searched all around, but they couldn't find a spare key.

Just when they were about to give up, #4 had an idea.

"Hey, remember that old rock we passed on the way here?" #4 said. "Maybe we can find a spare key there."

The others agreed, and they set off to find the rock. When they got there, they searched all around, but they couldn't find a spare key.

Just when they were about to give up, #1 had an idea.

"Hey, remember that old cave we passed on the way here?" #1 said. "Maybe we can find a spare key there."

The others agreed, and they set off to find the cave. When they got there, they searched all around, and finally, they found a spare key hidden behind a rock.

They were so relieved and happy. They rushed back to the car and drove home, grateful for their friendship and their ability to solve problems together.

The end.

## The Four Friends and the Haunted House

Once upon a time, there were four friends named #1, #2, #3, and #4. They were the best of friends and did everything together.

One day, they decided to go on a ghost hunting adventure. They had heard about a haunted house in the woods, and they wanted to see if it was true.

They packed their bags and set off on the long hike to the haunted house. When they finally arrived, they were excited and a little scared.

They went inside and started to explore. They went from room to room, looking for signs of ghosts.

But as they were exploring, they started to hear strange noises. They heard footsteps, whispers, and even screams.

They were getting scared, but they didn't want to give up. They kept exploring, determined to find the source of the noises.

Finally, they came to a room at the end of a long hallway. The door was locked, but they could hear something inside.

They tried to open the door, but it wouldn't budge. They were getting really scared now.

Just when they were about to give up, #1 had an idea.

"Hey, remember that old key we found in the woods?" #1 said. "Maybe it will open this door."

The others agreed, and they pulled out the old key. They tried it in the lock, and to their surprise, it worked.

They opened the door and went inside. And there, to their amazement, they saw a group of ghosts, sitting around a table, playing cards.

The ghosts looked up and saw the four friends. They were surprised, but they didn't seem angry.

"Who are you?" one of the ghosts asked.

"We're just some friends who came to explore the haunted house," #2 replied.

"Well, you're welcome to join us," the ghost said. "We were just about to have a snack. Would you like some?"

The four friends were shocked. They had never expected to be invited to have a snack with ghosts.

But they were also curious, so they agreed. And they sat down at the table with the ghosts and had a snack together.

They talked and laughed, and they learned that the ghosts were actually very nice. They had just been stuck in the haunted house for a long time, and they were happy to have some company.

The four friends left the haunted house feeling happy and amazed. They had never expected to make friends with ghosts, but they were glad they did.

The end.

They were so happy and excited. They couldn't believe they had found the treasure.

They were so happy and proud. They had worked together and achieved something amazing.

You can create a new role that has access to both User 1's and User 2's data. Then, you can assign this role to both User 1 and User 2. This way, both User 1 and User 2 will be able to see each other's data.

Here's how you can do it:

1. Go to the IAM console.
2. Click on "Roles" in the left-hand navigation menu.
3. Click the "Create role" button.
4. Select the "Another AWS account" trust policy.
5. Enter the AWS account number of the other user.
6. Click "Next: Permissions".
7. Attach the necessary policies to the role.
8. Click "Next: Tags".
9. Add any desired tags.
10. Click "Next: Review".
11. Enter a name and description for the role.
12. Click "Create role".

Now, you can assign this role to both User 1 and User 2. This way, both User 1 and User 2 will be able to see each other's data.

Note: This is just one way to do it. There are other ways to achieve the same result. The exact steps may vary depending on your specific use case and requirements.

 User.create!(name:  "Example User",
             email: "example@railstutorial.org",
             password:              "foobar",
             password_confirmation: "foobar",
             admin:     true,
             activated: true,
             activated_at: Time.zone.now)

 99.times do |n|
   name  = Faker::Name.name
   email = "example-#{n+1}@railstutorial.org"
   password = "password"
   User.create!(name:  name,
             email: email,
             password:              password,
             password_confirmation: password,
             activated: true,
             activated_at: Time.zone.now)
 end

 users = User.order(:created_at).take(6)
 50.times do
   content = Faker::Lorem.sentence(5)
   users.each { |user| user.microposts.create!(content: content) }
 end

 # Following relationships
 users = User.all
 user  = users.first
 following = users[2..50]
 followers = users[3..40]
 following.each { |followed| user.follow(followed) }
 followers.each { |follower| follower.follow(user) }

````

    if (answer.getAnswer().equals(answerToCheck)) {
        // do something
    }
}

### User 모델

User 모델은 사용자를 나타내는 모델이다. 사용자는 다음과 같은 정보를 가지고 있다.

* username: 사용자의 아이디
* password: 사용자의 비밀번호
* email: 사용자의 이메일 주소
* first\_name: 사용자의 이름
* last\_name: 사용자의 성
* is\_active: 사용자가 활성화되어 있는지 여부
* is\_staff: 사용자가 관리자인지 여부
* is\_superuser: 사용자가 최고 관리자인지 여부
* last\_login: 사용자가 마지막으로 로그인한 시간
* date\_joined: 사용자가 가입한 시간

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth.models import User

# 사용자 생성
user = User.objects.create_user(username='john', password='doe')

# 사용자 조회
user = User.objects.get(username='john')

# 사용자 수정
user.first_name = 'John'
user.last_name = 'Doe'
user.save()

# 사용자 삭제
user.delete()
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자를 인증할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth import authenticate

# 사용자 인증
user = authenticate(username='john', password='doe')

# 사용자 인증 여부 확인
if user is not None:
    print('사용자 인증 성공')
else:
    print('사용자 인증 실패')
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자를 로그인할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth import login

# 사용자 로그인
login(request, user)

# 사용자 로그아웃
logout(request)
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자를 로그인한 상태인지 확인할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth import is_authenticated

# 사용자 로그인 여부 확인
if is_authenticated(request):
    print('사용자 로그인 성공')
else:
    print('사용자 로그인 실패')
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자의 권한을 확인할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth import has_perm

# 사용자 권한 확인
if has_perm('app.permission', user):
    print('사용자 권한 있음')
else:
    print('사용자 권한 없음')
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자의 권한을 부여할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth.models import Permission

# 사용자 권한 부여
permission = Permission.objects.get(name='permission_name')
user.user_permissions.add(permission)

# 사용자 권한 취소
permission = Permission.objects.get(name='permission_name')
user.user_permissions.remove(permission)
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자의 그룹을 확인할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth.models import Group

# 사용자 그룹 확인
group = Group.objects.get(name='group_name')
if user in group.user_set.all():
    print('사용자 그룹 있음')
else:
    print('사용자 그룹 없음')
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자의 그룹을 추가할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth.models import Group

# 사용자 그룹 추가
group = Group.objects.get(name='group_name')
group.user_set.add(user)

# 사용자 그룹 취소
group = Group.objects.get(name='group_name')
group.user_set.remove(user)
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자의 비밀번호를 변경할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth.models import User
from django.contrib.auth.forms import PasswordChangeForm

# 비밀번호 변경 폼 생성
form = PasswordChangeForm(user=user)

# 비밀번호 변경 폼 유효성 검사
if form.is_valid():
    # 비밀번호 변경
    user.set_password(form.cleaned_data['new_password1'])
    user.save()
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자의 비밀번호를 재설정할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth.models import User
from django.contrib.auth.forms import PasswordResetForm

# 비밀번호 재설정 폼 생성
form = PasswordResetForm({'email': user.email})

# 비밀번호 재설정 폼 유효성 검사
if form.is_valid():
    # 비밀번호 재설정 이메일 전송
    form.save(request=request)
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자의 비밀번호를 재설정할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth.models import User
from django.contrib.auth.forms import SetPasswordForm

# 비밀번호 재설정 폼 생성
form = SetPasswordForm(user=user)

# 비밀번호 재설정 폼 유효성 검사
if form.is_valid():
    # 비밀번호 재설정
    user.set_password(form.cleaned_data['new_password1'])
    user.save()
```

User 모델은 다음과 같이 사용자의 비밀번호를 변경할 수 있다.

```python
from django.contrib.auth.models import User
from django.contrib.auth.forms import PasswordChangeForm

form = PasswordChangeForm(user=user)

# 비밀번호 변경 폼 유효성 검사
if form.is_valid():
    # 비밀번호 변경
    user.set_password(form.cleaned_data['new_password1'])
    user.save()
```

from django.contrib.auth.models import User
from django.contrib.auth.forms import PasswordResetForm

# 비밀번호 재설정 폼 생성
form = PasswordResetForm({'email': user.email})

���I'm not sure if this is the correct place to ask this question, but here it goes:

I'm trying to create an application in which the user can select a file from the file system and then the application will read the contents of the file. I'm using the following code to do this:

```
<input type="file" id="file" name="file" accept="text/plain" />
<button onclick="readFile()">Read File</button>

<script>
function readFile() {
    var file = document.getElementById("file").files[0];
    var reader = new FileReader();
    reader.onload = function(event) {
        var contents = event.target.result;
        console.log(contents);
    }
    reader.readAsText(file);
}
</script>
```

This works fine in Chrome and Firefox, but it doesn't work in Internet Explorer. I've read that this is because FileReader is not supported by Internet Explorer.

Is there any way to do this in Internet Explorer?

Comment: IE10 and up support FileReader.

## Answer (0)

You can use the `ActiveXObject` to read files in IE.

```
function readFile() {
    var file = document.getElementById("file").value;
    var fso  = new ActiveXObject("Scripting.FileSystemObject");
    var s = fso.OpenTextFile(file, 1);
    var contents = s.ReadAll();
    console.log(contents);
    s.Close();
}
```

���### 2.2.1. Synthesis of 1,2,3,4-Tetrahydroisoquinoline-3-Carboxylic Acid (1)

A mixture of 1,2-diaminobenzene (10 mmol), succinic anhydride (10 mmol), and acetic acid (10 mL) was stirred at 100°C for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was poured into ice-cold water (100 mL). The precipitate was filtered off, washed with water, and dried to give 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline-3-carboxylic acid (1) as a white solid. Yield: 85%. ^1^H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d~6~) δ 12.45 (s, 1H), 7.08 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.98 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.78 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 3.65 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 2.70 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 2.55 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H). ^13^C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d~6~) δ 171.5, 145.5, 130.0, 128.8, 117.8, 116.8, 41.2, 24.5, 24.4.

### 2.2.2. Synthesis of 1,2,3,4-Tetrahydroisoquinoline-3-Carboxylic Acid Methyl Ester (2)

To a solution of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline-3-carboxylic acid (1, 10 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) was added thionyl chloride (10 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was dissolved in methanol (10 mL). The solution was cooled to 0°C, and sodium methoxide (10 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was dissolved in water (10 mL). The solution was acidified with 1 M HCl to pH 2 and extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure to give 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline-3-carboxylic acid methyl ester (2) as a white solid. Yield: 90%. ^1^H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d~6~) δ 7.10 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.00 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.80 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 3.72 (s, 3H), 3.65 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 2.70 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 2.55 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H). ^13^C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d~6~) δ 169.5, 145.5, 130.0, 128.8, 117.8, 116.8, 52.2, 41.2, 24.5, 24.4.

### 2.2.3. Synthesis of 1,2,3,4-Tetrahydroisoquinoline-3-Carboxylic Acid Ethyl Ester (3)

To a solution of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline-3-carboxylic acid (1, 10 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) was added thionyl chloride (10 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was dissolved in ethanol (10 mL). The solution was cooled to 0°C, and sodium ethoxide (10 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was dissolved in water (10 mL). The solution was acidified with 1 M HCl to pH 2 and extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure to give 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline-3-carboxylic acid ethyl ester (3) as a white solid. Yield: 90%. ^1^H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d~6~) δ 7.10 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.00 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.80 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 4.15 (q, J = 7.0 Hz, 2H), 3.65 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 2.70 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 2.55 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 1.25 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H). ^13^C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d~6~) δ 169.5, 145.5, 130.0, 128.8, 117.8, 116.8, 60.5, 41.2, 24.5, 24.4, 14.5.

��  Question 1: What is the difference between the following two statements? 

Statement A: "I believe in the existence of God."

Statement B: "I have faith in God."

Answer: Statement A expresses a belief in the existence of God, while Statement B expresses a trust or reliance on God. While both statements may be used by religious individuals, they convey slightly different meanings.

Question 2: What is the difference between agnosticism and atheism?

Answer: Agnosticism is the belief that the existence of God or a higher power cannot be known or proven, while atheism is the lack of belief in the existence of God or a higher power. Agnostics are unsure or neutral on the matter, while atheists actively reject the idea of a higher power.

Question 3: What is the difference between a theist and a deist?

Answer: A theist is an individual who believes in the existence of a personal God who is actively involved in the world, while a deist is an individual who believes in the existence of a non-personal God who does not interfere with the world. Deists believe that God created the universe and set it in motion, but does not actively intervene in human affairs.

Question 4: What is the difference between monotheism and polytheism?

Answer: Monotheism is the belief in a single, all-powerful God, while polytheism is the belief in multiple gods or goddesses with varying levels of power and influence. Examples of monotheistic religions include Christianity, Islam, and Judaism, while examples of polytheistic religions include Hinduism and Ancient Greek religion.

Question 5: What is the difference between a religion and a spiritual belief system?

Answer: A religion typically includes a set of beliefs, practices, and rituals that are organized around a specific deity or deities, while a spiritual belief system is a more individualized set of beliefs and practices that may or may not be associated with a particular religion. Spiritual belief systems may emphasize personal experiences, intuition, and connection with nature or a higher power, while religions often have more formal structures and institutions.

Question 6: What is the difference between a sect and a cult?

Answer: A sect is a small group that splits off from a larger religious group and maintains many of the same beliefs and practices, while a cult is a small group that has distinct and often extreme beliefs and practices that differ significantly from those of the larger society. Cults may also have a charismatic leader who exercises a high level of control over members, while sects typically have more democratic decision-making processes.

Question 7: What is the difference between a denomination and a religion?

Answer: A denomination is a subgroup within a larger religious tradition that has its own beliefs, practices, and organizational structure, while a religion is a distinct system of beliefs and practices that is not part of a larger tradition. For example, Baptists and Methodists are denominations within Christianity, while Christianity, Islam, and Judaism are separate religions.

Question 8: What is the difference between a theocracy and a secular government?

Answer: A theocracy is a form of government in which religious leaders hold political power and make decisions based on religious principles, while a secular government is one in which religious beliefs and practices are separated from political decision-making. In a secular government, religious freedom is protected, but religious institutions do not have official political power.

Question 9: What is the difference between a sacred text and a holy book?

Answer: A sacred text is a written work that is considered holy or inspired by a higher power, while a holy book is a specific type of sacred text that is revered and studied within a particular religious tradition. For example, the Bible is a holy book for Christians, while the Quran is a holy book for Muslims.

Question 10: What is the difference between a spiritual experience and a religious experience?

Answer: A spiritual experience is a personal, often transcendent, experience that connects an individual to a higher power or a sense of ultimate meaning, while a religious experience is a similar experience that is associated with a particular religious tradition or community. Religious experiences may involve specific rituals, practices, or symbols that are unique to a particular faith, while spiritual experiences may be more individualized and personal.

Question 11: What is the difference between a mystic and a spiritualist?

Answer: A mystic is an individual who seeks direct, personal experience of the divine or ultimate reality, often through meditation, contemplation, or other spiritual practices. A spiritualist, on the other hand, is an individual who believes in the existence of spirits or ghosts and may use mediumship or other forms of communication to contact them. While both mystics and spiritualists may be interested in spiritual matters, their practices and beliefs differ significantly.

Question 12: What is the difference between a prophet and a seer?

Answer: A prophet is an individual who receives divine revelation or messages from a higher power and is called to share those messages with others. A seer, on the other hand, is an individual who has the ability to perceive hidden or future events through supernatural means. While both prophets and seers may be associated with religious traditions, their roles and abilities differ.

Question 13: What is the difference between a saint and a holy person?

Answer: A saint is an individual who has been officially recognized by a religious institution as having lived a life of exceptional holiness, often with a reputation for miracles or other supernatural phenomena. A holy person, on the other hand, is an individual who is considered to be deeply spiritual or pious, but has not been officially recognized as a saint.

Question 14: What is the difference between a monk and a friar?

Answer: A monk is an individual who lives in a monastery, follows a strict set of rules and practices, and is dedicated to a life of prayer, contemplation, and service. A friar, on the other hand, is a member of a religious order who lives in community with other friars, but is also engaged in active ministry in the world. Friars may work as teachers, preachers, or social workers, and often have more contact with laypeople than monks.

Question 15: What is the difference between a nun and a sister?

Answer: A nun is an individual who lives in a convent, follows a strict set of rules and practices, and is dedicated to a life of prayer, contemplation, and service. A sister, on the other hand, is a member of a religious community who lives in community with other sisters, but is also engaged in active ministry in the world. Sisters may work as teachers, nurses, social workers, or in other roles that serve the needs of the community.

Question 16: What is the difference between a shaman and a priest?

Answer: A shaman is an individual who serves as a mediator between the spiritual world and the physical world, often using rituals, trances, or other techniques to access spiritual realms and communicate with spirits or ancestors. A priest, on the other hand, is an individual who is ordained to perform religious rituals and ceremonies, often as part of a larger religious institution. While both shamans and priests may serve spiritual roles, their practices and beliefs differ significantly.

Question 17: What is the difference between a guru and a spiritual teacher?

Answer: A guru is an individual who is considered to be a spiritual master or teacher, often with a reputation for enlightenment or spiritual insight. A spiritual teacher, on the other hand, is an individual who provides guidance and instruction in spiritual practices or beliefs, but may not have the same level of authority or prestige as a guru.

Question 18: What is the difference between a mosque and a temple?

Answer: A mosque is a place of worship for Muslims, often with a mihrab (a niche indicating the direction of Mecca) and a minbar (a pulpit for sermons). A temple is a place of worship for various religions, including Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism, often with images or symbols of deities and a focus on meditation or other spiritual practices.

Question 19: What is the difference between a synagogue and a church?

Answer: A synagogue is a place of worship for Jews, often with a Torah scroll and a bimah (a platform for reading the Torah). A church is a place of worship for Christians, often with a cross or other Christian symbols and a focus on the sacraments or other religious rituals.

Question 20: What is the difference between a monastery and a convent?

Answer: A monastery is a community of monks who live together in a secluded location, often with a focus on prayer, contemplation, and manual labor. A convent is a community of nuns who live together in a secluded location, often with a focus on prayer, contemplation, and service to the community. While both monasteries and convents are religious communities, their practices and focus differ.

���## Answer (1)

You can use the following query to get the result:

```
SELECT
    `t1`.`id`,
    `t1`.`name`,
    `t1`.`parent_id`,
    `t2`.`name` AS `parent_name`,
    `t1`.`created_at`,
    `t1`.`updated_at`
FROM
    `categories` AS `t1`
        LEFT JOIN
    `categories` AS `t2` ON (`t1`.`parent_id` = `t2`.`id`)
WHERE
    `t1`.`parent_id` IS NULL OR `t1`.`parent_id` = 0
ORDER BY
    `t1`.`name` ASC
```

�������������������������I’m not sure what I was expecting when I picked up this book, but it wasn’t this. I was expecting a light, fluffy romance, but what I got was a deep, emotional story about love, loss, and forgiveness.

The story is told from the perspective of two characters, Lara Jean and Peter. Lara Jean is a shy, introverted girl who has never had a boyfriend. She’s always been content to live in her own little world, but when her older sister leaves for college, she’s forced to grow up and face the real world. Peter, on the other hand, is the popular, athletic guy who has always had his pick of girls. But when his girlfriend dumps him for his best friend, he’s left feeling lost and alone.

The two of them strike up an unlikely friendship when Lara Jean’s older sister leaves behind a box of love letters that she had written to her crushes over the years. One of those crushes is Peter, and when he finds out about the letters, he convinces Lara Jean to pretend to be his girlfriend in order to make his ex-girlfriend jealous.

At first, the arrangement is just supposed to be for show, but as they spend more time together, they start to develop real feelings for each other. But their relationship is complicated by the fact that Lara Jean is still in love with her sister’s ex-boyfriend, Josh, and Peter is still hung up on his ex-girlfriend.

The story is beautifully written, with characters that are complex and relatable. I loved how the author explored the themes of love, loss, and forgiveness, and how she showed that sometimes, the most important thing is to forgive yourself.

Overall, I would highly recommend this book to anyone who is looking for a deep, emotional story about love and forgiveness. It’s a beautiful, heartwarming book that will leave you feeling all the feels.

حَدَّثَنَا عَبْدُ اللَّهِ بْنُ يُوسُفَ، حَدَّثَنَا عَبْدُ الرَّزَّاقِ، أَخْبَرَنَا مَعْمَرٌ، عَنْ هِشَامِ بْنِ عُرْوَةَ، عَنْ أَبِيهِ، عَنْ عَائِشَةَ، قَالَتْ كَانَ رَسُولُ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم إِذَا أَرَادَ أَنْ يَتَوَضَّأَ قَالَ ‏ "‏ بِسْمِ اللَّهِ ‏"‏ ‏.‏ فَإِذَا أَتَى الْمَاءَ قَالَ ‏"‏ أَعُوذُ بِاللَّهِ مِنَ الشَّيْطَانِ الرَّجِيمِ ‏"‏ ‏.‏ فَيَغْسِلُ وَجْهَهُ وَيَمْسَحُ بِيَدِهِ عَلَى رَأْسِهِ وَيَمْسَحُ بِيَدِهِ عَلَى وَجْهِهِ وَيَغْسِلُ يَدَيْهِ إِلَى الْمَرَافِقِ ثَلاَثَ مَرَّاتٍ ‏.‏ ثُمَّ يَمْسَحُ بِيَدِهِ عَلَى رِجْلَيْهِ وَيَغْسِلُ رِجْلَيْهِ إِلَى الْكَعْبَيْنِ ‏.‏ ثُمَّ يَقُولُ ‏"‏ أَشْهَدُ أَنْ لاَ إِلَهَ إِلاَّ اللَّهُ وَحْدَهُ لاَ شَرِيكَ لَهُ وَأَشْهَدُ أَنَّ مُحَمَّدًا عَبْدُهُ وَرَسُولُهُ ‏"‏ ‏.‏

## Bengali
১/১০১। আয়েশা (রাঃ) থেকে বর্ণিত। তিনি বলেন, রাসূলুল্লাহ সাল্লাল্লাহু আলাইহি ওয়াসাল্লাম যখন উযূ (ওজু/অজু/অযু) করতেন তখন তিনি বলতেনঃ আল্লাহর নাম উচ্চারিত করে ফেলি। অতঃপর তিনি পানি নিয়ে বলতেনঃ আল্লাহর নিকট আশ্রয় চাইঃ শয়তান থেকে রক্ষা দেওয়া চাই। তারপর তিনি তাঁর মুখ ধৌত করতেন, তাঁর হাত দ্বারা তাঁর মাথা মাসেহ করতেন, তাঁর হাত দ্বারা তাঁর মুখ মাসেহ করতেন, তাঁর হাত দ্বারা তাঁর দু’হাত ধৌত করতেন তিনবার। তারপর তাঁর হাত দ্বারা তাঁর দু’পা মাসেহ করতেন এবং তাঁর দু’পা ধৌত করতেন তিনবার। অতঃপর তিনি বলতেনঃ আমি শহাদত করতে থাকি যে, আল্লাহ তা’আলা একমাত্র ইলাহ এবং তাঁর সাথে কোন শরীক নেই। আর আমি শহাদত করতে থাকি যে, মুহাম্মাদ (সা.) তাঁর বান্দা ও রাসূল।

���## Answer (2)

You can use the following regex:

`^(?=.*[0-9])(?=.*[a-z])(?=.*[A-Z])(?=.*[!@#$%^&*])(?=.{8,})`

Explanation:

- `^` - Start of string
- `(?=.*[0-9])` - Positive lookahead for a number
- `(?=.*[a-z])` - Positive lookahead for a lowercase letter
- `(?=.*[A-Z])` - Positive lookahead for an uppercase letter
- `(?=.*[!@#$%^&*])` - Positive lookahead for a special character
- `(?=.{8,})` - Positive lookahead for at least 8 characters

Comment: This is a good answer, but it doesn't match the OP's requirement of "at least one digit, one lowercase letter, one uppercase letter, one special character, and one whitespace character".

��  Question 10:  What is the difference between an array and an ArrayList?
Answer:  An array is a fixed-size data structure, meaning that once it is created, its size cannot be changed. An ArrayList, on the other hand, is a dynamic data structure that can grow or shrink as needed. Additionally, an ArrayList provides more functionality than an array, such as the ability to add and remove elements, and to easily iterate over its contents.

Question 11:  What is the difference between an abstract class and an interface?
Answer:  An abstract class is a class that cannot be instantiated, but can provide a partial implementation for its subclasses. An interface, on the other hand, is a collection of abstract methods that define a contract for classes that implement it. A class can implement multiple interfaces, but can only inherit from one abstract class.

Question 12:  What is the difference between checked and unchecked exceptions?
Answer:  Checked exceptions are exceptions that are checked by the compiler at compile-time, and must be handled or declared in a method's signature. Unchecked exceptions are exceptions that are not checked by the compiler and can occur at runtime. Examples of unchecked exceptions include NullPointerException and ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

Question 13:  What is the difference between final, finally and finalize?
Answer:  Final is a keyword used to denote that a variable, method or class cannot be overridden or modified. Finally is a block of code that is executed after a try-catch block, regardless of whether an exception is thrown or not. Finalize is a method that is called by the garbage collector before an object is destroyed, and is used to perform any cleanup tasks.

Question 14:  What is the difference between equals() and == in Java?
Answer:  The equals() method is used to compare the contents of two objects, while the == operator is used to compare the memory addresses of two objects. Therefore, two objects can be equal in terms of their contents, but not in terms of their memory addresses.

Question 15:  What is the difference between overloading and overriding in Java?
Answer:  Overloading is when two or more methods have the same name but different parameters, while overriding is when a subclass provides a specific implementation for a method that is already defined in its superclass. Overloading is determined at compile-time, while overriding is determined at runtime.

Question 16:  What is the difference between a stack and a queue?
Answer:  A stack is a Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) data structure, meaning that the last element added to the stack is the first one to be removed. A queue, on the other hand, is a First-In-First-Out (FIFO) data structure, meaning that the first element added to the queue is the first one to be removed.

Question 17:  What is the difference between a HashMap and a TreeMap?
Answer:  A HashMap is an unordered collection of key-value pairs, while a TreeMap is an ordered collection of key-value pairs, where the keys are sorted in ascending order. Additionally, a HashMap provides constant-time performance for the basic operations (get and put), while a TreeMap provides log(n) time performance.

Question 18:  What is the difference between a LinkedList and an ArrayList?
Answer:  A LinkedList is a doubly-linked list data structure, where each element is a node that contains a reference to the previous and next nodes. An ArrayList is a dynamically-resizable array data structure, where elements are stored in contiguous memory locations. A LinkedList provides constant-time performance for add and remove operations at the beginning or end of the list, while an ArrayList provides constant-time performance for get and set operations.

Question 19:  What is the difference between a checked and an unchecked exception in Java?
Answer:  A checked exception is an exception that is checked by the compiler at compile-time, and must be handled or declared in a method's signature. An unchecked exception is an exception that is not checked by the compiler and can occur at runtime. Examples of unchecked exceptions include NullPointerException and ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

Question 20:  What is the difference between a superclass and a subclass in Java?
Answer:  A superclass is a class that is extended by another class, while a subclass is a class that extends another class. A subclass inherits the properties and methods of its superclass, and can also provide its own implementation for those methods. A class can have only one superclass, but can have multiple subclasses.

Question 21:  What is the difference between a static and a non-static inner class in Java?
Answer:  A static inner class is a class that is defined inside another class, but does not have access to the outer class's instance variables and methods. A non-static inner class, on the other hand, is a class that is defined inside another class and has access to the outer class's instance variables and methods.

Question 22:  What is the difference between a raw type and a parameterized type in Java?
Answer:  A raw type is a type that is not parameterized with any type arguments, while a parameterized type is a type that is parameterized with one or more type arguments. For example, List<String> is a parameterized type, while List is a raw type.

Question 23:  What is the difference between a covariant return type and a contravariant parameter type in Java?
Answer:  A covariant return type is a return type that is a subtype of the overridden method's return type, while a contravariant parameter type is a parameter type that is a supertype of the overridden method's parameter type. Covariant return types allow a subclass to return a more specific type than the overridden method, while contravariant parameter types allow a subclass to accept a more general type than the overridden method.

Question 24:  What is the difference between a transient and a volatile variable in Java?
Answer:  A transient variable is a variable that is not serialized when an object is serialized, while a volatile variable is a variable that is shared between multiple threads and is used to ensure visibility and ordering of memory operations.

Question 25:  What is the difference between a checked and an unchecked cast in Java?
Answer:  A checked cast is a cast that is checked by the compiler at compile-time, and may result in a ClassCastException if the cast is not valid. An unchecked cast is a cast that is not checked by the compiler and can result in a ClassCastException at runtime.

حَدَّثَنَا عَبْدُ اللَّهِ بْنُ يُوسُفَ، حَدَّثَنَا سُفْيَانُ، عَنْ عَمْرِو بْنِ دِينَارٍ، عَنْ عَبْدِ اللَّهِ بْنِ عَبَّاسٍ، قَالَ قَالَ رَسُولُ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم ‏ "‏ إِذَا أَرَادَ الرَّجُلُ أَنْ يَتَزَوَّجَ فَلْيَنْظُرْ إِلَى ثَلاَثَةِ خِصَالٍ فَإِنْ وَجَدَهَا فِي امْرَأَةٍ فَلْيَتَزَوَّجْهَا وَإِنْ لَمْ يَجِدْهَا فَلاَ بَأْسَ لَهُ فِي تَزَوُّجِ غَيْرِهَا فَالَّذِي يَتَزَوَّجُ لِلْخِيَارِ فَهُوَ أَفْضَلُ وَالَّذِي يَتَزَوَّجُ لِلْعِيَارِ فَهُوَ أَدْنَى وَالَّذِي يَتَزَوَّجُ لِلْعَوْرَةِ فَهُوَ أَشَدُّ بَأْسًا ‏"‏ ‏.‏

SahihShuaib Al Arnaut

## Bengali
২/২০৫৫। আবদুল্লাহ ইবনু আব্বাস (রাঃ) থেকে বর্ণিত। তিনি বলেন, রাসূলুল্লাহ সাল্লাল্লাহু আলাইহি ওয়াসাল্লাম বলেছেনঃ যখন কেউ বিবাহ করার ইচ্ছা করে, তখন তাকে তিনটি ব্যক্তিতের চেষ্টা করতে হবে। যদি তা তিনটি ব্যক্তিতে থাকে, তাহলে সে তাকে বিবাহ করবে। আর যদি তা না থাকে, তাহলে তাকে অন্য কেউ বিবাহ করার অনুমতি থাকবে। যে ব্যক্তি ভাল ব্যক্তির বিবাহ করে, সে সবচেয়ে উত্তম। যে ব্যক্তি খুদরাতের বিবাহ করে, সে সবচেয়ে নীচ। আর যে ব্যক্তি ছেদচাপ ব্যক্তির বিবাহ করে, সে সবচেয়ে বেশি ক্ষতি পাবে।
Grade
SahihAl-Albani
SahihMuhammad Fouad Abd al-Baqi
SahihShuaib Al Arnaut
Sahih MuslimZubair Ali Zai
References:
Hadith No2055
Arabic No2055
ReferenceBook 11 Hadith 198
## English
It was narrated from 'Abdullah bin 'Abbas that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said:“When a man intends to get married, let him look at three things: Her lineage, her religion and her wealth. If he finds all three in a woman, let him marry her. If he does not find all three, let him look for them in another woman. The one who marries for lineage, he is the best of them. The one who marries for beauty, he is the most base of them. The one who marries for wealth, he is the most evil of them.”
Grade
SahihAl-Albani
SahihMuhammad Fouad Abd al-Baqi
SahihShuaib Al Arnaut
Sahih MuslimZubair Ali Zai

���## Answer (1)

You can use the following regex:

`^(?=.*[a-z])(?=.*[A-Z])(?=.*[0-9])(?=.*[!@#$%^&*])[a-zA-Z0-9!@#$%^&*]{8,20}$`

Explanation:

- `^` - Start of the string
- `(?=.*[a-z])` - At least one lowercase letter
- `(?=.*[A-Z])` - At least one uppercase letter
- `(?=.*[0-9])` - At least one digit
- `(?=.*[!@#$%^&*])` - At least one special character
- `[a-zA-Z0-9!@#$%^&*]{8,20}` - Length between 8 and 20 characters
- `$` - End of the string

���I'm not sure if this is the right place to ask this question, but I'll give it a shot.

I'm currently working on a project where I'm trying to use a Raspberry Pi 4 to control a 16-channel relay module. I'm using the GPIO pins on the Pi to send signals to the relay module, which then controls various devices.

I'm using the RPi.GPIO library in Python to control the GPIO pins. I've written a script that turns on and off each relay in sequence, and it works fine when I run it from the command line. However, when I try to run the script as a service, it doesn't seem to work.

Here's what I've done so far:

1. Created a new service file in /etc/systemd/system called relay.service:
```bash
[Unit]
Description=Relay Control Service
After=multi-user.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/python3 /home/pi/relay_control.py
Restart=always
User=pi
Group=gpio
StandardOutput=inherit
StandardError=inherit
SyslogIdentifier=relay

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```
2. Enabled the service:
```
sudo systemctl enable relay
```
3. Started the service:
```
sudo systemctl start relay
```
4. Checked the status of the service:
```
sudo systemctl status relay
```
The status shows that the service is active (running), but the relays don't seem to be turning on and off like they do when I run the script from the command line.

I've tried adding some debug statements to the script, but I'm not seeing any output in the system logs. I've also tried running the script as the pi user from the command line, and it works fine.

Does anyone have any ideas on what might be going wrong here? Is there something special I need to do to get a Python script that uses the RPi.GPIO library to run as a service?

Thanks in advance for any help you can provide!

**EDIT:**

I should also mention that I've tried adding the following lines to the script to set the GPIO mode and numbering:
```python
import RPi.GPIO as GPIO

# Set GPIO mode and numbering
GPIO.setmode(GPIO.BCM)
GPIO.setwarnings(False)
```
I've also tried adding the following lines to the service file to set the environment variables for the GPIO library:
```bash
Environment="GPIO_MODE=BCM"
Environment="GPIO_WARNINGS=False"
```
But neither of these changes seem to make a difference.

**EDIT 2:**

I should also mention that I've tried running the script as a different user (not pi), and it still doesn't work. I've also tried changing the User and Group fields in the service file to root, and it still doesn't work.

I've also tried adding some debug statements to the script to print out the state of the GPIO pins, and it looks like they're not being set to HIGH or LOW like they should be when the script is run as a service.

I'm starting to think that there might be some sort of permissions issue that's preventing the script from accessing the GPIO pins when it's run as a service.

**EDIT 3:**

I've tried adding the following lines to the service file to give the pi user permission to access the GPIO pins:
```bash
PermissionsStartOnly=true
ExecStartPre=/usr/bin/sudo -u pi /opt/vc/bin/vcgencmd set_permissions gpio 0777
```
But it still doesn't work.

I've also tried adding the following lines to the service file to run the script as the root user:
```bash
User=root
Group=root
```

  )

  99.times do |n|
    name  = Faker::Name.name
    email = "example-#{n+1}@railstutorial.org"
    password = "password"
    User.create!(
      name:  name,
      email: email,
      password:              password,
      password_confirmation: password,
      activated: true,
      activated_at: Time.zone.now
    )
  end

  # Microposts from the users
  100.times do |n|
    content = Faker::Lorem.sentence(5)
    users = User.order(:created_at).take(6)
    user  = users[n % users.size]
    user.microposts.create!(content: content)
  end

      follow = User.all.order('RANDOM()').first
    end

ē  Question:  What is the difference between the 2008 and 2012 versions?

 Answer:  The 2012 version has a new feature that allows you to create a customized list of your most frequently used commands, which can be accessed by clicking on the "Favorites" button.  The 2012 version also has improved compatibility with Windows 8 and later versions of Windows.

Question:  How do I create a new document in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To create a new document in Microsoft Word, click on the "File" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then select "New" from the menu on the left.  This will open a new blank document.  You can also use the keyboard shortcut "Ctrl + N" to create a new document.

Question:  How do I save a document in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To save a document in Microsoft Word, click on the "File" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then select "Save" or "Save As" from the menu on the left.  This will open the "Save As" dialog box, where you can choose a location to save the document and give it a name.  You can also use the keyboard shortcut "Ctrl + S" to save the document.

Question:  How do I print a document in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To print a document in Microsoft Word, click on the "File" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then select "Print" from the menu on the left.  This will open the "Print" dialog box, where you can choose a printer and set any desired print options.  You can also use the keyboard shortcut "Ctrl + P" to print the document.

Question:  How do I insert a table in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To insert a table in Microsoft Word, click on the "Insert" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Table" button in the "Tables" group.  This will open a menu where you can choose the number of rows and columns for the table.  You can also use the "Draw Table" option to create a custom table by drawing the rows and columns with your mouse.

Question:  How do I insert a picture in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To insert a picture in Microsoft Word, click on the "Insert" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Pictures" button in the "Illustrations" group.  This will open a dialog box where you can choose the picture you want to insert.  You can also use the "Online Pictures" option to search for and insert pictures from the internet.

Question:  How do I format text in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To format text in Microsoft Word, you can use the buttons in the "Font" group on the "Home" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen.  These buttons allow you to change the font, font size, font style, and font color of the selected text.  You can also use the buttons in the "Paragraph" group to change the alignment, indentation, and spacing of the selected text.

Question:  How do I insert a page break in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To insert a page break in Microsoft Word, click on the "Page Layout" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Breaks" button in the "Page Setup" group.  This will open a menu where you can choose the type of break you want to insert.  To insert a page break, select "Page" from the menu.

Question:  How do I insert a hyperlink in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To insert a hyperlink in Microsoft Word, select the text or object that you want to turn into a hyperlink, then click on the "Insert" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen.  In the "Links" group, click on the "Hyperlink" button.  This will open the "Insert Hyperlink" dialog box, where you can enter the URL or choose a location within the document to link to.

Question:  How do I insert a footnote in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To insert a footnote in Microsoft Word, click on the "References" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Insert Footnote" button in the "Footnotes" group.  This will insert a footnote at the bottom of the page and automatically insert a marker at the point in the text where the footnote was inserted.  You can then enter the footnote text in the footnote area at the bottom of the page.

Question:  How do I insert a header or footer in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To insert a header or footer in Microsoft Word, click on the "Insert" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Header" or "Footer" button in the "Header & Footer" group.  This will open the "Header & Footer" tools, where you can choose a pre-designed header or footer or create your own.  You can also use the buttons in the "Header & Footer" group to insert page numbers, dates, and other elements.

Question:  How do I track changes in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To track changes in Microsoft Word, click on the "Review" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Track Changes" button in the "Tracking" group.  This will turn on the track changes feature, which will highlight any changes made to the document and allow you to accept or reject those changes.  You can also use the buttons in the "Tracking" group to add comments and mark up the document.

Question:  How do I create a mail merge in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To create a mail merge in Microsoft Word, click on the "Mailings" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Start Mail Merge" button in the "Start Mail Merge" group.  This will open the "Mail Merge" pane, where you can choose the type of document you want to create (such as a letter or email) and select the data source for the merge (such as an Excel spreadsheet or a database).  You can then use the buttons in the "Write & Insert Fields" group to insert merge fields into the document.  When you are ready to merge the document, click on the "Finish & Merge" button in the "Finish" group.

Question:  How do I insert a page number in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To insert a page number in Microsoft Word, click on the "Insert" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Page Number" button in the "Header & Footer" group.  This will open a menu where you can choose the location and format for the page number.  You can also use the buttons in the "Header & Footer" group to insert other elements, such as the date or the current time.

Question:  How do I insert a table of contents in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To insert a table of contents in Microsoft Word, click on the "References" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Table of Contents" button in the "Table of Contents" group.  This will open a menu where you can choose the style and format for the table of contents.  You can also use the "Update Table" button to update the table of contents with any changes made to the document.

Question:  How do I insert a citation or bibliography in Microsoft Word?

 Answer:  To insert a citation or bibliography in Microsoft Word, click on the "References" tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click on the "Citations & Bibliography" button in the "Citations & Bibliography" group. **LoginBean.java**

```
import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.enterprise.context.SessionScoped;
import javax.inject.Named;

@Named
@SessionScoped
public class LoginBean implements Serializable {

private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;

private String username;
private String password;

public String getUsername() {
    return username;
}

public void setUsername(String username) {
    this.username = username;
}

public String getPassword() {
    return password;
}

public void setPassword(String password) {
    this.password = password;
}

public String login() {
    if (username.equals("admin") && password.equals("admin")) {
        return "success";
    } else {
        return "error";
    }
}

}

 User.create!(
     name:  "Example User",
     email: "example@railstutorial.org",
     password:              "foobar",
     password_confirmation: "foobar",
     admin: true,
     activated: true,
     activated_at: Time.zone.now
   )
  99.times do |n|
    name  = Faker::Name.name
    email = "example-#{n+1}@railstutorial.org"
    password = "password"
    User.create!(
      name:  name,
      email: email,
      password:              password,
      password_confirmation: password,
      activated: true,
      activated_at: Time.zone.now
    )
  end

  # Following relationships
  users = User.all
  user  = users.first
  following = users[2..50]
  followers = users[3..40]
  following.each { |followed| user.follow(followed) }
  followers.each { |follower| follower.follow(user) }

  # Create topics
  topics = []
  10.times do
    topics << Topic.create!(
      name: Faker::Lorem.word,
      description: Faker::Lorem.sentence
    )
  end

  # Create posts
  posts = []
  topics.each do |topic|
    10.times do
      posts << Post.create!(
        title: Faker::Lorem.word,
        content: Faker::Lorem.paragraph,
        user: users.sample,
        topic: topic
      )
    end
  end

  # Create comments
  comments = []
  posts.each do |post|
    10.times do
      comments << Comment.create!(
        content: Faker::Lorem.paragraph,
        user: users.sample,
        post: post
      )
    end
  end

end

ff. #NBAFinals pic. \n\n— GoldenStateWarriors (@warriors) June 10, 2017

The Warriors are the first team to win the NBA Finals in five games since the 2007 San Antonio Spurs.

Durant was named the NBA Finals MVP for the first time in his career. He averaged 35.2 points, 8.4 rebounds and 5.4 assists in the five-game series.

"I couldn't sleep for two days," Durant said. "I couldn't really eat. Just 24/7 thinking about this moment, how great it would feel to be champions, how great it would feel to win a championship with this unbelievable group of teammates. I couldn't let them down. I couldn't let the city of Oakland down. I couldn't let these fans down."

Durant, who joined the Warriors last summer in free agency, is the first player to win the NBA Finals MVP with two different teams. He won the award in 2012 as a member of the Oklahoma City Thunder.

"I'm just so happy for him," Warriors coach Steve Kerr said. "He's been through so much. He's had so many questions about his decision to come here. And what I'm proudest of is he made his decision strictly as a basketball player. He came here to try to win a championship. He came here to be a great teammate. He came here to grow as a player. And he did all of that."

Durant, 28, is the third-youngest player to win the award, behind Magic Johnson and Kawhi Leonard.

"I couldn't see it happening any other way," Warriors forward Draymond Green said. "I knew he was built for this. I knew he was built for this moment. I knew he was going to come in and be the closer that we needed. He's been that all year long. He's been that in the playoffs. He's been that these Finals. He's been unbelievable. He's been a Finals MVP. And he's been a champion. And that's all he wanted. That's all he wanted was a chance to play for a championship. And he got that. And he took advantage of that."

Durant is the 11th player to win the award in his first season with a team, joining Moses Malone, Cedric Maxwell, Magic Johnson, James Worthy, Hakeem Olajuwon, Clyde Drexler, Shaquille O'Neal, Tim Duncan, LeBron James and Kevin Garnett.
